questions.question: Which of the following would be the best initial test to diagnose erythrasma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wood's lamp examamination Explanation: Wood's lamp examination is the initial diagnostic tool used to confirm Erythrasma . It is a superficial skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, obesity, immunocompromised state, hyperhidrosis, and older adults. It usually presents as asymptomatic lesions in the following areas: Interdigital: Scaling, fissuring plaques, maceration. Intertriginous (between skin folds): Hyperpigmented patches, mild scaling, wrinkling. Genital/perianal: Pruritis ani Interdigital erythrasma commonly occurs with dermatophyte or candidal infections. Wood's lamp examination shows coral-red fluorescence from coproporphyrin III produced by Corynebacterium minutissimum. Treatment: First line: Topical antibacterials (Fusidic acid, Clarithromycin) or topical antifungal (Miconazole) Second line: Photodynamic therapy using porphyrin Microscopy with KOH (Option A): It is commonly used to diagnose fungal infections like dermatophyte or candidal infection. ( Images : Left - Candidal infection; Right - Tinea versicolor) Dermatoscope Examination (Option C) : This tool is primarily used for evaluating pigmented skin lesions. It is not diagnostic for erythrasma but is useful for identifying melanomas and other skin cancers and tumours. Skin Culture (Option D) : Small shiny, whitish-grey colonies with coral-red fluorescence would be observed in a culture. However, a Wood's lamp examination can be performed in the clinic, offering a more immediate diagnosis and treatment.

questions.question: The image shows a 2-year-old boy brought to the clinic with complaints of rashes on his face. On examination, he has plaques covered with honey-coloured crust. There is no history of fever or any constitutional symptoms. Which is the best stain to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Gram stain Explanation : The child has a superficial bacterial infection of the skin known as impetigo. It is most commonly seen in children. Clinical features: It has two clinical variants Bullous impetigo Non-bullous impetigo/Impetigo contagiosa Age group Newborns Preschoolers/toddlers Organism Staphylococcus aureus Both streptococcus and staphylococcus Staphylococcus is more commonly seen in developed nations. Streptococcus is more commonly seen in developing nations. Type of crust Varnish crust Crusted erosions covered by honey-coloured crust. Lesion Superficial bullae - MC Site Trunk Face (predilection towards peri-oral and peri-nasal areas) Complication Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) Diagnosis: Gram stain/ culture is done to ascertain the causative organism. Gram’s stain shows gram-positive cocci arranged in grape-like clusters Management: Localized skin involvement: Wash skin, remove the crust, and use disinfectants. Topical antibiotic for 1 week Extensive skin involvement, bullous disease and/or lymphadenopathy: Treat as for localized skin involvement plus systemic antibiotics First line antibiotics:- Flucloxacillin, Cloxacillin. Second-line antibiotics:- Macrolides such as erythromycin, and clarithromycin. Third-line antibiotics:- Trimethoprim and Tetracyclines. Tzanck smear (Option A) : Performed to diagnose the Pemphigus disorders (see image). Also used in the diagnosis of herpes KOH stain

questions.question: A 43-year-old man presents with a fever (100.4°F) and a skin lesion on the right leg that appeared 2 days ago. He also complains of redness over his ear since yesterday. He sustained a minor laceration in the same location 1 week ago when he fell into his rose bushes while gardening. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Erysipelas Explanation: Erysipelas is a skin infection that usually affects the upper half of the dermis but may also extend to the superficial cutaneous lymphatics. It occurs due to the entry of bacteria through a breach in the skin barrier. Erysipelas is most commonly caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci. Clinical features: It manifests as an area of erythema that is well-demarcated and raised around the edges. Acute-onset constitutional symptoms like fever, chills, and malaise are also present. O/E erythematous lesions

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with a painful, erythematous skin rash over his leg that started two days ago and has been consistently increasing with a history of fever for the past two days. On examination, a tender, erythematous rash with ill-defined margins is visible. The local rise in temperature is present. There are no fluctuant nodules. Which is the most common causative organism for the infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Beta-hemolytic streptococci Cellulitis is an acute bacterial infection involving the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue of the skin. It occurs when bacteria enter through a breach in the skin

questions.question: A 27-year-old woman presents with complaints of severely itchy rashes all over her body that developed after she had used the hot tub in a hotel. On examination, she has multiple, monomorphic, erythematous papules and pinhead pustules over hair follicles, predominantly over her trunk and buttocks. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa Based on the given clinical scenario, the patient has pseudomonas folliculitis or hot tub folliculitis, an infection of the skin commonly associated with swimming pool and hot tub use. Risk factors include changes to cutaneous flora, female gender, length of exposure, and skin trauma. Within 48 hours of exposure, it presents as pruritic papules and papulopustules ranging from two to ten millimetres in diameter. It most often presents on the flanks, axillae, buttocks, and ears. Management can vary with the severity of the infection. In most cases, lesions are self-limited and resolve without management in one to two weeks. In severe cases, antipseudomonal agents like ticarcillin and piperacillin can be given. Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): Folliculitis caused by staph aureus is also known as Bockhart impetigo. The classical presentation of crops of domed yellow pustules involving hair follicles. Usually heals spontaneously but sometimes becomes chronic. Streptococcus pyogenes (Option B): Streptococcus pyogenes causes infections in the Superficial keratin layer (impetigo), The superficial dermis (erysipelas), The deep dermis & subcutaneous tissue (cellulitis), The fascia (necrotizing fasciitis), or Muscle (myositis and myonecrosis). Cellulitis: Corynebacterium minutissimum (Option C): Erythrasma is a bacterial infection of the skin typically caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This pathogen infects the stratum corneum in warm and wet areas of the skin. Most commonly, the axillary, inguinal, and interdigital regions are affected.

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents to his dermatologist with complaints of foul odor and discomfort on the soles of his feet when wearing closed shoes for prolonged periods. Upon examination, small, shallow pits on the heels and the balls of the feet are present. Which of the following features is not associated with this condition?

options.A: Associated with reduced or no sweat production
options.D: It is a superficial bacterial infection

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Associated with reduced or no sweat production Explanation: Pitted keratolysis is a superficial bacterial infection (Option D) of the stratum corneum, commonly caused by Corynebacterium species. Risk factors include Warm and moist environments (hyperhidrosis, swimmers, wet work) (Option C) Most commonly affects the weight-bearing areas of the foot. (Option B) Conspicuous, discrete, shallow, circular lesions with a punched I out appearance coalesce in places to produce irregular erosions. There is occasionally green or brown discolouration of the horny layer. Hyperhidrosis is often associated, sometimes with maceration, stickiness and a foul odour. Management: First line: Topical antibiotics (Fusidic acid) +/- Benzoyl peroxide Botulinum toxin for hyperhidrosis Aluminium chloride Reference: Chapter 26: Bacterial infections. In: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology. 9th ed. Blackwell; 2016. p. 26.42-26.43 Barankin B. 2023. Pitted keratolysis. UpToDate

questions.question: A young man presents with coarse axillary hair, foul-smelling sweat, and yellow, waxy nodules on the hair shafts that can be easily scraped off, with no pain or itching. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Trichomycosis nodosa Explanation: Trichomycosis axillaris (AKA Trichomycosis nodosa) is a superficial bacterial infection of the hair shafts caused by Corynebacterium spp (Most commonly C. flavescens) It presents as sheath-like nodules over the hair shafts, which may appear red, yellow, or black, predominantly observed in axillary hair. Sweaty and malodorous axillae are common symptoms, with no pain and itching. Pubic infection can also occur (Trichomycosis pubis). Investigations typically reveal narrow bacillary organisms on KOH mount, Gram-positive coccobacillary structures on Gram stain, and yellow-white or yellow-green fluorescence under Wood's lamp. Treatment involves the use of Aluminium chloride as an antiperspirant. questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with nail discoloration, as shown in the image. She has a history of recurrent nail infections but has never noticed changes like these before. Which of the following diseases could be caused by the responsible pathogen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All the above Explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image suggest the diagnosis of Green nail syndrome caused by Pseudomonas aeroginosa (Gram-negative bacilli). Skin infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa can result from either direct contact or as secondary seeding from bloodstream infections. These infections include, Green nail syndrome Toe web infection Hot tub folliculitis Malignant external otitis Ecthyma gangrenosum P. aeruginosa subcutaneous nodules Necrotizing skin and soft tissue infections Burn wound infections Infection Description Green nail syndrome It is characterised by onycholysis and greenish discolouration of the nail bed. The green colour is due to pyocyanin, a green pigment produced by bacteria. Ecthyma gangrenosum (Option A) It is classically associated with P. aeruginosa sepsis and bacteremia in immunocompromised patients. It typically presents as painful, erythematous papules that progress to necrotic ulcers with surrounding erythema. The lesions can rapidly evolve into deep ulcers with black eschars. Hot tub folliculitis/ Pseudomonas folliculitis (Option B) Caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which thrives in warm, moist environments like hot tubs and swimming pools with inadequate chlorine levels. It presents as itchy, red monomorphic papules or pustules around the hair follicles of the trunk. Malignant external otitis (Option C) Typically affects immunocompromised individuals. questions.question: A 3-year-old child presents with a 2-day history of fever, irritability, and erythema starting around the perioral region, which quickly spreads to the face, trunk, and extremities. The child develops large, fragile bullae that rupture easily, leaving a moist, erythematous base. A positive Nikolsky sign is noted. There is no mucosal involvement, and the child has no recent history of medication use. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome Explanation: The presence of a positive Nikolsky sign and the characteristic clinical features of severe blistering skin condition, suggests the diagnosis of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS). In this condition, exfoliative toxin 1 produced by Staphylococcus aureus binds to Desmoglein-1, leading to a subcorneal (intraepidermal) split. Clinical features: Macular erythema and skin pain that progresses to flaccid bullae Thick perioral crusting gives a ‘ dry oatmeal appearance ’ A positive Nikolsky sign is seen The mucous membrane is not involved Constitutional symptoms Diagnosis: Clinical presentation and examination are adequate for diagnosis Biopsy is indicated when the diagnosis is suspicious. A frozen section of the sloughed epidermis (skin biopsy) can confirm SSSS by revealing intraepidermal separation caused by exfoliative toxins. Treatment: Immediate hospital admission, intravenous antibiotic therapy, and the initiation of supportive measures. IIIIIII Stevens-Johnson syndrome (Option B): This condition typically involves mucosal lesions and often follows recent drug exposure, which is not the case here. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (Option C): TEN usually involves more extensive skin detachment and mucosal involvement, along with a more severe, widespread erythema.
